title: Chapter 11 – Conditional Logic Checkpoint
description: Quick concept-check for chapter 11. Test your understanding of if, elif, else, comparisons, and logical operators.

questions.prompt: Which operator is used in Python to check if two values are equal?

explanations.overview: Use == to compare values; = is for assignment.

byOptionId.a: This is the assignment operator, not comparison.
byOptionId.b: Correct – == checks if two values are equal.
byOptionId.d: <> is not the standard equality operator in Python.

questions.prompt: What happens when the condition in an if statement is False and there is no else?

options.label: The code inside the if is skipped.
The code inside the if still runs.

explanations.overview: If a condition is False and there is no else, Python just skips that block.

byOptionId.a: Python does not show an error in this case.
byOptionId.b: Correct – the indented block under if is ignored.
byOptionId.c: The code runs only if the condition is True.
byOptionId.d: The rest of the program can still continue.

questions.prompt: What does elif do in Python?

options.label: It means 'else if' – another condition checked only if previous ones were False.
It is always run at the end, like finally.
It has no meaning; it's just decoration.

explanations.overview: elif lets you chain multiple conditions after an if.

byOptionId.a: Correct – elif checks another condition if earlier ones were False.
byOptionId.b: Unlike finally in other languages, elif is conditional.
byOptionId.c: Functions are defined with def, not elif.
byOptionId.d: elif is an important keyword, not decoration.

questions.prompt: Which condition is True only when both a and b are True?

explanations.overview: The and operator requires both sides to be True.

byOptionId.a: or is True if at least one side is True.
byOptionId.b: Correct – a and b is only True when both are True.
byOptionId.c: not a just flips the value of a.
byOptionId.d: a != b checks if they are different, not both True.

questions.prompt: When does the else part of an if/else statement run?

options.label: When the if condition is True.
When the if condition is False.
Never; else is ignored by Python.

explanations.overview: else covers the 'otherwise' case when the if condition is False.

byOptionId.a: If True, only the if block runs, not else.
byOptionId.b: Correct – else runs when the if condition is False.
byOptionId.c: else always comes after if, not before.
byOptionId.d: else is part of Python's control flow and is not ignored.
